abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Project Performance
            Assessment Report (PPAR) for four structural adjustment
            lending operations to Colombia from 2001 to 2005. The
            overall rating for all the four projects is rated as
            satisfactory in the Implementation Completion Report (ICR)
            rating, and also the performance of the Bank and the
            Borrower for all four projects is rated as satisfactory. The
            main lessons learned from this review are: (i) as noted in
            Independent Evaluation Group (IEG's) ICR Review of
            Fiscal and Institutional Adjustment Loan (FIAL III), project
            design needs to be clearly aligned with its development
            objectives in order to attain the latter. Even if the
            structural deficit of the central administration is
            "highly sensitive and political" as the ICR
            states, the magnitudes of these structural rigidities were
            such that they must be addressed if progress is to be made
            in achieving the substantial fiscal adjustment that is
            required for sustained macroeconomic stability; (ii) loans
            with large numbers of objectives and conditions, and
            involving too many institutions relative to the management
            capacity of the Government and the Bank itself, overtax the
            implementation capacity of both the Bank and the borrower
            and result in poor execution; (iii) the inclusion of
            objectives of widely different levels of priority and weak
            connection with the ultimate goals of the operations tends
            to obscure the degree of attainment of the latter; and (iv)
            success depends on the borrower's ownership of the
            objectives of the loan.
